#summary How to translate AdBlock into your own language

!AdBlock supports translation into many languages.  But there is only one problem: we don't speak all languages ourselves. We need your help!

Here's how to translate !AdBlock into your own language:

= Don't waste your time =

Make sure that Chrome [http://code.google.com/intl/en/chrome/webstore/docs/i18n.html#localeTable supports your language code]. If it's not supported, we can only use your translation for Safari.

Also, check the [http://code.google.com/p/adblockforchrome/issues/list?can=1&q=type%3Dl10n+-status:duplicate+-status:invalid&sort=summary&colspec=ID+Status+Summary&x=area&y=priority&cells=tiles list of existing translations] to make sure !AdBlock isn't already translated into your language.  If it is, you can leave a comment on the list entry saying you'd like to help, and the original translator or we will talk to you.

= OK, let's translate! =

First, [http://code.google.com/p/adblockforchrome/issues/entry?template=Offer%20to%20translate add your language] to the list of translations (so that two people don't start the same translation at the same time).

Then visit [http://chromeadblock.com/l10n/ chromeadblock.com/l10n/].
Enter the language code in the text box (the one listed on [http://code.google.com/intl/en/chrome/webstore/docs/i18n.html#localeTable this page]).
Now you can start translating. Every text box shown on that page contains the current translation (if any), the original English message and a description. All of these text boxes should be translated into your language.

However, there are a few exceptions:
 * The word {{{AdBlock}}} should not be translated -- it is a name.
 * Words wrapped between {{{$}}} should not be translated -- they refer to placeholders. For example, if you see {{{$updatelink$}}} in your text, that part of the text will be replaced by the content of the textbox {{{updatelink}}} a few lines lower.
 * Make sure to leave {{{$1}}}, {{{$2}}}, etc in your translation -- they are placeholders for strings that !AdBlock will insert, such as "{{{<a href='...'>}}}" and "{{{</a>}}}", or the input of a user.

For example, if I want to translate the following string:
{{{
Please first $updatelink$ to the newest version of AdBlock
}}}
it might look like this:
{{{
Ya $updatelink$ iss var gut so yoo do eet to AdBlock noww
}}}
And $updatelink$ will be translated a few lines lower. If it first looks like
{{{
$1update$2
}}}
it could now look like
{{{
$1get der file all quicklike$2
}}}

Note some things about my (pretend) translation:
  * I didn't translate "updatelink" (that is a placeholder)
  * I translated one word in "content" into five, but made sure to keep the $1 and $2
  * I moved $updatelink$ earlier in "message" because it sounded better there in my language

If a message contains {{{<b>}}}, {{{<i>}}}, {{{<a>}}}, or {{{<br/>}}}, your translation should as well:
 * Make text *bold* by wrapping it in {{{<b>}}} and {{{</b>}}} like {{{<b>Hi!</b>}}}
 * Make text _italic_ by wrapping it in {{{<i>}}} and {{{</i>}}} like {{{<i>Hi!</i>}}}
 * Make text a [# hyperlink or a button] by wrapping it in {{{<a>}}} and {{{</a>}}} like {{{<a>click me</a>}}}
 * Add newlines by adding {{{<br/>}}} like {{{First line<br/>Second line}}}

=== Don't want to use the web page? ===
If you for some reason don't want to use the [http://chromeadblock.com/l10n/ chromeadblock.com/l10n/ web page], you can still help translating. It'll just be a bit more difficult.
Right click [http://adblockforchrome.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/_locales/en/messages.json this link] and download the English messages.json file. Open that file (in any text editor, like Notepad), and you'll see a lot of entries that look like this one:
{{{
  "updatefromoldversion": {
    "message": "You are using an old version of AdBlock. Please first $updatelink$ the newest version of AdBlock",
    "description": "Instruction telling the user to click a link to update AdBlock",
    "placeholders": {
      "updatelink": {
        "content": "$1download$2",
        "example": "<a href='http://chrome.com/update_here.ctx'>download</a>"
      }
    }
  },
}}}
Every string on *a line that starts with "message" or "content" *needs to be replaced with a translation. However, do not translate the strings "message" or "content", just the string that follows them. The same rules apply as for the web interface.
The above example might look like this after you translated it:
{{{
  "updatefromoldversion": {
    "message": "Ya $updatelink$ iss var gut so yoo do eet to AdBlock noww",
    "description": "Instruction telling the user to click a link to update AdBlock",
    "placeholders": {
      "updatelink": {
        "content": "$1get der file all quicklike$2",
        "example": "<a href='http://chrome.com/update_here.ctx'>download</a>"
      }
    }
  },
}}}



= Finished? =
Click the export button at the bottom of the page. It'll search for errors now. If any errors are found, you'll see an message and the page will jump to the bad translation.
After all errors (if any) are fixed, click the download link. Save the file to your local computer and then attach your file to your entry in the [http://code.google.com/p/adblockforchrome/issues/list?can=1&q=type%3Dl10n+-status:duplicate+-status:invalid&sort=summary&colspec=ID+Status+Summary&x=area&y=priority&cells=tiles list of translations].  We'll take care of the rest!
